title: What will be the closing value for the pound against the euro on 1 November 2019?
preds:
Now that A50 is happening - there was no effective change post-announcement.
It rose from 1.111 Oct 10 very sharply to 1.16 and has been now hovering tightly around 1.16.
I would have thought the news about the A50 extension would have sent it higher, but it did not.
So the likelihood is high the this is where it will close this week.
Since things go down much faster than they go up - I have the chance of "down" 2x that of going "up"
Tight range of trading, Brexit on the back burner until next year, and little economic news in the next 3 days.
Adjusting the forecast to increase certainty given the distance to the close date.

What will be the closing value for the pound against the euro on 1 November 2019? Range bound Euro and a swinging Pound make for a boucy average. A UK election may move the Pound but EU elections are over.

I'm inclined to suspect that the relevant markets have been making Brexit adjustments all along, so there won't be much movement unless there is a big surprise.  If there is one such, the direction of movement will of course depend on what the surprise is.

Updating due to the passage of time, stalled time table for Brexit is presenting headwinds, but the pound would need to fall 5% to hit 1.1 - outside view is pretty unlikely for that drastic a move in 8 days. Inside view that there is little that can be done (outside the EU denying an extension) in the next week to drive such as shift. As such, 33% feels like sufficient - even overly-conservative - downside protection. After all...this is FX

Given the increased likelihood of further delay to Brexit, I imagine the current rate to remain stable. Some possible downside risk with the delay causing more confusion/frustration/unrest, but fundamentally nothing should change in such a short period of time
as I've reasoned before most Brexit risks factored in long ago and Sterling trading comfortably within certain limits for the time-being.

(Oct 22nd) The exchange rate in the past year (according to Google) appears to have been range bound in the 1.1 to 1.2 levels with the prospect of no deal seeming to have pushed it towards the lower end of that spectrum and tipping into the 1-1.1 range. The announcement of a re-negotiated option with the EU has pushed the rate back above the 1.15 level suggesting that the market is assuming that no deal will not happen at month end and that there is an option on the table that will enable either an extension or a deal to pass the house of commons. Cannot fully guarantee the outcome will stay in this bracket though as there is still room for Brexit to suddenly turn, or for non-Brexit related issues to drive the exchange rate agenda. That same Google search shows a 5yr exchange rate range bound in the 1.05-1.44 so would take a major issue to push the exchange rate to the extremes of the forecasting range

GBP:EUR at 1.16271 - and it had been steady at this level for all of last week. Even with an A50 extension - the uncertainty re: Brexit will at least solidify current levels - with a possible shoot-up over 1.20 slight more thinkable in the time remaining.

In the wake of the Letwin Amendment's passage on Saturday, the 'crash out' probability appears to be way down, which I assume will keep the £ from dropping back below €1.10.  And as Commons Speaker Bercow has denied the motion for an 'up or down vote', and we're now expecting the Withdrawal and Agreement Bill to be debated, it seems most likely that at the very least there will be no 'crash out.'  As I've tried to explore in other related questions, I see it now better than 50% that the government will be frustrated, that the House (and Lords) won't approve a deal before 31 October, and the extension will be granted.  That would I expect keep the pound steady, and not see it shoot up over  €1.20.  The passage of the Withdrawal Agreement Bill by the end of the month can't be ruled out however, as the government's 306 votes on Saturday, and various vote tallies suggest, given the number of 'rebel Tories' and Labour defectors they got on board for the Letwin Amendment vote.
Optics of negotiations have been providing upside for the £ - still waiting to see if deal can be agreed - that should help £ strengthen significantly - however not convinced at this stage -

One scenario is that the UK crashes out of the EU, and the pound crashes vs the US dollar.  But a hard Brexit is forecast to also hurt the euro, so I'm reducing the chances that the pound will fall below parity with the euro by a couple of percentage points.  The chance that there will be a deal seem to have increased, and the pound has been strong.  So I'm adding those two points to the 1.20-1.30 answer.

Rising pound will likely give back gains in the event of an extension, but stay above 1.1, a hard Brexit will likely push it below 1.1, I think a deal is unlikely to send the pound above 1.2, but can see a small sliver of outcomes

the pound making its move in light of Oct 15 announcements re: possible understanding on the Irish backstop and the preliminary garnering the necessary votes on Parliament to pass a WA.
The possibility of GBP "overshooting" now also exists if currency market speculators get ahead of themselves
A slight correction still seems likely, but no-deal appears to be less so, allowing for an increase in the exchange rate up to approx 1.10

Base rate: The historical average rate (1999-today) is 1.33459. Purchasing Power Parity: Using Purchasing Power Parity theory, specifically, comparing the price of a Big Mac in the UK versus one in the Eurozone, suggests a rate of about 1.24.   Relative Economic Strength: Quarter-on-quarter economic growth rates (data from the Office of National Statistics in the UK and Eurostat for the Eurozone), indicates that the average quarter-on-quarter growth of the last six quarters in the UK is 0.31% and for the Eurozone, is 0.417%. This is a soft case for Euro appreciation. The European Central Bank's interest rate is -0.50% and the Bank of England's bank rate is 0.75%.  The higher interest rate in the UK will attract those investors looking to earn the highest yield on investments, whereas the negative interest rate in the Eurozone will attract borrowers or carry-trade speculators. I believe that this tilts marginally in favour of the GBP in the long-run. Expectations: Expectations are largely framed by the biggest geopolitical event governing relations between the two, in decades: Brexit. My reading is that markets expect an extension on negotiations and a delay on Brexit, (pamphlets obtained by the BBC imply that the Tories are preparing for a delay on Brexit) and confirmation of this should give the Pound a boost. No Deal will hurt the Pound, at least in the short-term, and that short-term could be over by Nov 1.  Forecast: As I write, the GBP-Eur rate is 1.1499. My feeling is, there will be a delay on Brexit, but I am not sufficiently bullish on that to write-off the chances of a No Deal Brexit -Brexit with a deal suggests Parliament approving a deal the vast majority will not have read, a staggering dereliction of duty-. There is, of course, a marginal chance that the rate swims between 1.00 and 1.10 -for now, I am dismissing the possibility given that the last time the GBP-Eur last nearly hit 1.0 was in the wake of the 2008 crisis and the UK was in the throes of a deep recession-. I think even with a hard Brexit, the markets have baked much of that in so the downside risk is lower than if No Deal was completely unexpected. I think fair value for the GBP-Eur sits at 1.19-1.29 but the question is when does the GBP-Eur start to move within that range?
Will give more time to settle brexit, same as before
Based on where it’s sitting now
if brexit happened cleanly a sharp rise of the GBP, however i think it is not going to be so clean and different aspects could prevent a sharp rise, currenta 1 year avg 1.13 with 7% volatility

closed at 1.14 today.
was 1.15 last week from 1.10 - speculation is the happy talk in the papers of a "detailed and constructive discussion" - whatever that means.
Could GBP be strengthening merely on the belief of an orderly exit - whether WA or A50?
Latest results from Random Walk model. Combined with my other forecast that a no-deal Brexit likelihood is no more than a few % points.

The pound has just jumped to 1.149 euro, right in the middle of the 1.10 to 1.20 range.  Interestingly, the consensus view, at 46%, is that the correct answer is 1.00 to 1.10.  I have no idea how the UK-EU talks are going, and the consensus view may very well be correct.  Events will change fast during the remainder (no pun intended) of October. So for now I'm betting with the currency traders.  They could be wrong, but they have real money on the line.  And they follow Brexit events much more closely than I ever could.

Intraday Oct futures fell to 1.09 euros before settling back to 1.12 euros.
It spent last week at 1.12
Some technicians I found predict a breakout downwards at 1.08 euros
I felt that the ratio spending much of today day at 1.09 was a technical test of recent lows.
If it breaks through 1.08, the ratio could weaken further - meaning further pound weakness.
It may be that the markets were unsettled at the Scottish court decision - maybe feeling a slightly higher chance of a hard Brexit?
Adjusting up based on Brexit expectations and a higher probability of an extension

pound staying in the 1.10-1.20 range through September - until Friday when BOE spokesman says rate cuts might be needed even if hard Brexit avoided - which would/did weaken the pound.
Support appears at 1.119
October futures indicate 1.1273, while Nov futures indicate 1.126. Pretty steady (too steady?)
The above presumes a steady-state environment.
The environment is not steady-state. 
The range of political options is from hard Brexit to National Unity gov't and A50 extension, followed by general election.
I believe a hard Brexit will be avoided - thus mid-range estimates of 1.0 to 1.2.
A slight favoring of 1.10+ due to futures market indications
Adjustments are coming back to where I think things will be based on continued craziness on the other side of the pon.

Sterling peaks usually caused by signs Britain not leaving Euro. Not higher than 1.2. Bad news rarely causes dips below 1.10, so firm base for prediction. Most likely situation Nov 1st is transition deal, leading to spike, but most likely not higher than 1.2. EU devaluing Euro with QE could push as high as 1.3.

Adjusting up. Risks still remain on the downside, but it seems like a soft Brexit or extension is the base case for the next month. Beyond that uncertainty remain, but the facts still remain 
- Benn’s Bill protects the UK from a hard Brexit
- Johnson will likely get a vote of no confidence if he can’t deliver a Brexit Major risk is still the EU saying “enough” and forcing the UK out

A lot of 'baked in' hedges made over past two years plus real possibility now of fresh referendum mean a probable return to figures that represent no decisive swing either way in Brexit at that particular date.

I don't know if Brexit will happen on October 31st or not.  Price action of the pound indicates that the market believes that the chances of a hard Brexit are reduced.  But I don't believe anyone really knows how this will end.  So I'll keep my eye on the chart, with the idea that people who are betting real money know more than me. The pound has rather unexpectedly strengthened.  It's at nearly 1.13 euro.  At 47% the crowd still believes it will weaken to 1.0-1.1 euro per pound, and I've been betting on the same, but with a 61% chance.  I'll cut back the chances for the pound falling below parity, and increase the weighting that it stays in the current 1.10-1.2 range.

I think there will be a Brexit deal along the lines of Mrs May's deal, which is the softest of Brexit deals suggested in terms of affect on GDP. The pound would rise further in time towards what it was before the Brexit vote (although not all the way) but there is still a lot of negotiating to do after the deal, hence just above it's present value.
Other than that the date will be extended which will drop the value of the pound but not below 1 to 1.
No deal remains the main likelihood

I'm only learning the stock market so this is based on instinct & public perception. Strength recognises strength, weakness doesn't, and thus far there hasn't been a great deal of strength on display. Some current EU countries are looking to the U.K. to show that strength, and I believe it will reflect in the price of the pound post-Brexit. Maybe not on the 31st, perhaps a day or two later depending on when the announcement takes place, but either way the pound will be going up against the Euro.
pound strengthening since Sep 4 les to upward revision to "1.10-1.20" tranche, and adjustments everywhere else
Interest in currency rates. I don't think there will be huge fluctuations as leaving will be detrimental to both the Euro and the pound
The UK economy is relatively strong, but that matters little to 'investors' so the pound will take a hit from them for personal gain.
No deal Brexit won't happen on October 31, but there will a general election in a few weeks. The opinion polls will predict a hung parliament.
A good chance of no or bad deal
Brexit (negotiated or not) will affect both currencies so their value against each other will remain around 1.10. There will probably more fluctuation against other currencies.
With a no deal Brexit looking less likely, and an extension more likely, I am expecting Sterling holders to be reassured.
Uncertainty will bring the pound down
The markets seem to have factored in the likelihood of no deal

The reason for me predicting that pound will be below 1.00 against the euro by the 1st November, is due to the current exchange rate at the minute, currently the pound stands at 1.12 against the euro, and with the possibility of a no deal Brexit and the chance that once again Brexit ,may be delayed there is a high probability that the pound against the euro will drop again, as it's unlikely for Britain and the members of the European Union to come to a fair and successful deal.
currently ~1.23 - very low historically, but concerns may fade over time as people get more used to what will happen.
Import tax on Chinese products makes dollar too much stronger than pound.

Forex Most traded market in the world, the count of transactions daily is overwhelming.  That means it’s almost impossible to predict a trend until more certainty is settle around how Brexit unfolds - too many bias & points of view will be traded until then, too fragmented.

On Nov 1st, there is likely to be more certainty in the British financial markets -- one way or another.
This will lead to less volatility in the value of sterling. However, in a weakened position, the pound will only likely go down in value.
I think the market has priced in BJ and a GE.
High uncertainty, but it seems that a new delay is in order.

The pound sank after PM Johnson arrived in July - and has now firmed very strongly with the Parliamentary votes Tuesday and Wednesday forbidding hard Brexit, and the Opposition not likely to agree to a General Election if the PM calls for one. Both events argue for an extension - and that is favorable for the pound. Upon reflection - the currency markets seemed to be ahead of this. The ratio rolled straight down after the PM took over in early July, but then swung over to the upside Sun/Mon Aug 11/12, and never looked back from 1.0646 - in spite of all the tough talk towards the EU and the reaffirmations of hard Brexit happening in August. 1.1173 seems to be the upcoming resistance point from the present 1.10741.

Since the referendum the ceiling has been 1.19 [circa] - recent developments [Johnson as new PM / No Deal Brexit risk] has shocked market participants and pound dropped to its lowest level 1.07 against the Euro for some time - if parliament removes no deal risk pound will rise again - however new levels of 'unknowns' - general election outcome etc - extension of Article 50 looks probable so that parliament can set agenda for election before exit so that country is given 'deciding vote' - essentially mp's looking to involve country in debate as it has been clear for 3yrs mp's have not been able to agree on much at all - Tory govt under Johnson will offer Brexit - Liberals will be party of Remain [revoke Article 50] - Labour position is unclear - this alone should weigh heavily on the pound - lots more will happen in between now and 31st October that should influence this forecast - will be reviewing this one over the next few weeks
The pound had its lowest drop since 2017 today

The pound has already declined as the markets have started factoring in a potential no-deal outcome. It seems likely to decline further but perhaps not below 1.0 and I am guessing there is still a chance of a minor rebound if any further extension is introduced.

I think there will be a general election which will postpone Brexit. The uncertainty will cause markets to drive the pound lower. In the unlikely scenario the U.K. does leave the EU, there could be an upswing because at least the decision has been made.

Crash out on 10/31 eems unlikely but still possible.  Calling of an election or other dramatic event is also possible but unlikely. Narrowing my forecast range to reflect that and shorter time horizon.
depends on so many factors but based on the current uncertainty we see and the value now and that there will still be many unanswered questions at that time i have been cautious.
The market has already accounted for Brexit no-deal with the small chance of a deal. But the deal is still no ideal.
I think Boris will have a majority by then and will leave the EU on Oct 31st. However, the relative values of the currencies will not change much.
There will be no data on what effect a post Brexit scenario is having. Market caution will drive the value of the pound down initially. It may bounce quickly if it's not as bad as feared.
I don't think the UK will have left the EU by this date, but the uncertainty will stop any major gains against the current valuation below 1.20

Rate is the around the 10 year low. likley no-deal brexit will weaken british economy in the short term due to uncertainty. this will likely cause money traders to sell GBP as Nov 1 approaches, looking to profit in the medium term as stability returns.

Where there is news of no deal, the pound has consistently dropped. If the UK leaves without one, the pound will drop partly forced by financial speculation, as with the vote itself. However, I think a deal is likely. With recession looming in the eurozone, if the deal is halfway reasonable the pound will see a jump against the euro.

Currently at 1.10 
With Brexit, pound will have a topsy turvy journey. Pound will for a moment lose power in global market as an international currency. 
Brexit May see some inflation due to import duties and that will spiral a degrowth in consumption. 
Central reserve will increase for pound and with lower balance of payment, pound will have an idle layover for a brief period making it lose more power against euro and usd

If the no-deal Brexit is stopped, then I'd think the pound will rise signficantly. As of 30 Aug, it's still above $1.20, so as I see it, the most likely scenario is that it remains in the $1.20 to $1.30 range.  But maybe, even if the no-deal option is blocked, and the EU agrees to an extension, it could still drop, and doesn't have far to go to get below $1.20.  Going further, if Jeremy Corbyn can't swing a no-confidence vote, and Boris Johnson gets his parliamentary suspension, then the crash-out becomes most likely, and the pound should drop, I would think, precipitously.  I can't see it going below parity with the dollar though.

If we get a No-Deal Brexit (50%) on 31st Oct then the pound will wake up the next morning with a severe headache, even though it will recover a bit later on. If we get an encouraging deal (25%) the pound may bounce back a bit, albeit cautiously.  If we get another delay (25%) then it will probably continue to bump around where it is now.
Believe deal will happen through Irish backstop tinker, but effectively May's deal goes through, but ushers in long period of negotiation, so low chance of huge rise.

UK will enter into a currency adjustment process should there be a hard exit. 
I also have a high chance of an outcome of more delays and reflection processes to deal with the Irish border.
Both parties have much to lose in a hard Brexit. There will be more compromise and the value of sterling will go up accordingly.
Updated - previous forecast was based on USD/GBP, not EUR/GBP
USD will remain strong, both Euro and pound have political uncertainties.
a deal without the irish backstop or with alternatives to it will be agreed
a deal without the irish backstop or with alternatives will be agreed
Based on recent trend, it is more likely to be higher than 1.10 than between 1.00 and 1.10. Brexit, volatility is going to influence this in negative way to pound. ie. Conversion going above 1.10
Known no deal Brexit deadline and companies are more prepared. No much recovery time but will improve against a weakening USD.

This question differs from other financial questions in that it ends on a day, during which a higher than normal volatility can be expected. I update my forecast by applying a new method to account for this. The new model has 2 steps. 1) Project price on Oct 31 similarly to how other financial questions are modeled, using a Geometric Random Walk model [1]. This model uses historical frequencies in daily price changes from the last 10 years. In other words, it assumes the distribution of future scenarios will be based on the *long-run* historical volatility. Since we know that the long-run historical volatility is likely not representative of November 1, we need step 2: 2) Project the price on November 1. I multiply the projected distribution of prices on Oct 31 from step 1) by a random change. How large can this change be? Since we expect greater than usual volatility, I took the 10 most volatile days in in the historical data and built a distribution. The average percent change among these 10 days (absolute value) was actually not very large (3%). The model selects a certain daily change at random and applies it to the Oct 31 price. By repeating this process many times, I get a distribution of all possible futures. Result from step 1 for distribution of price on Oct 31: 0.2, 40.39, 58.06, 1.35, 0.0 Result after step 2 for distribution of price on Nov 1: 1.4, 41.57, 51.61, 5.4, 0.0 ~~~
Inside View
~~~ This result is perhaps somewhat surprising given that one may expect Brexit to lead to a lot of volatility. But what the historical data shows us is that for the  pound-euro pair there is not much precedent that would justify high percentages in the 1st and 4th or 5th buckets. One reason why we may not expect these buckets to materialize is that the fortunes of the EU and the UK often move in tandem, meaning the currency pair does not see as much volatility as the GBP-USD for example. My assumption is that in this particular case as well, volatility related to Brexit will impact both the euro and the GBP, and subsequently mute impacts on the pound-euro pair. I am still keeping a slightly wider distribution than suggested by the model, since to some degree Brexit is an unprecedented event. [1] https://github.com/EmilDim/GJO/blob/master/RandomWalk.ipynb

Current GBP value is political in nature. Any predictions must consider a no-deal Brexit or late deal, the result of which will greatly swing the final outcome. Current pointers suggest a no-deal is the most likely outcome, however the government is more likely to step in and block with and delay exit planning. Assuming Brexit is delayed, GBP will raise slightly but not make major gains until resolution is achieved.
The pound is likely to collapse below 1.00 if a no deal Brexit occurs on 31 October 2019. At the end of August the pound was trading at 1.107 with very little apparent upside.
The market tends to overreact initially but

The pound has fluctuated with all of the variability in leadership this year.  I think that many have come to the conclusion that a no deal Brexit is the most likely outcome. The real question for the pound is the likelihood of a global recession which may outweigh the Brexit concerns.
Likely to stay where it is with the market waiting to see how things go.

Euro vs sterling rate has already priced in the possibility of no-deal brexit therefore the worst possible outcome is roughly where we are at now with the current rate. If we do get a deal then the pound will only increase against the Euro.

There is no sign of a reasonable plan emerging to handle Brexit, so it looks increasingly likely that Britain  will simply crash out of the EU. That is already being priced in to the exchange rate to some degree.

I have updated my forecast as I believe that the a Hard Brexit may already be priced in at an exchange rate above 1.00. I still believe that some sort of hard or disorderly Brexit is the most likely outcome. In the event this does not take place on schedule I believe that the continued uncertainty will not be a bullish signal to markets, indicating a rate below 1.10 as the most likely outcome.
Likely to reduce but not enormously. Most risk already known. Reasonable chance some policy decisions might make it stronger, probably just by a small amount. Small but real risk of it going to ~1
Seems Johnson determined to come out on 31st

GBP appreciated with news that Macron and Merkel were open to certain negotiation. The Economist says it is not the case, so it will go down again as the date gets closer, but not further than 1.05. Only alternative is a new delay (BoJo invested heavily against this) or Parliament rejection of no-deal.  https://www.economist.com/britain/2019/08/22/boris-johnsons-german-and-french-dealings

Much of the potential devaluation from no deal Brexit are already factored into market sales over the past two years. The price remains stable within certain boundaries at the moment so despite uncertainties as to whether parliament will block no deal or Boris will call General election and attempt to get more traction in parliament the outlook remains within those boundaries because most hedging positions have already been made.

Brexit has been a three year process that businesses have priced into their forecasts and models. Although a no-deal brexit scenario would likely lead to greater losses by the pound relative to the euro, it likely will not be significant make the Euro worth more than the pound due to Brexit alone.
Should stay more or less the same. Brexit is not new news to markets. Businesses have already adapted.
In recent months, the value has hovered between just below 1.10 and 1.20.

If Brexit is cancelled then I don't see the currency recovering swiftly. On the other hand the pound is undervalued at the moment given the good state of economy. I believe that if this prediction is updated it is likely that a greater % will be given to the higher values.
Euro is still strong, Pound should weaken with Brexit

Historic low for the last five years: 1.02
Ever since Brexit vote, rate was around 1.1

Today (26 August 2019) the rate is 1.10. It rose from 1.06 (10 Aug). this rise is, I believe, due to relatively positive reporting about the possibility of the UK government striking some sort of deal with the Eu, in order to begin the Brexit transition. However, I believe the EU will offer no fundamental concessions on the deal previously agreed with Theresa May (because they can't, without undermining the "Four Pillars"). Further, I think it's unlikely Johnson will achieve a hard brexit on October 31st. I think it is more like that Parliament will somehow block a no deal, and knowing this, I believe there is a possibility of a General Election, but the timing of that is difficult to predict. All in all, I think "more of the same - but nervy" is how things will play out and come November the first I expect the rate to be lower than 1.10 but not drastically so - and slightly above 1.10 is, in my estimation, a good possibility. My preferred range would actually be 1.05 to 1.15 etc...

The pound currently hovers around 1.0 Euros. As a Brexit without a deal is likely, it is unlikely to recover quickly. A Deal with the US might help the recovery but it will be a bad deal for Britain. If the regulatory monetary Monitor (no idea about the name)  in Britain acts it will increase.

Despite their hard-line stance, EU leaders must want to avoid a no-deal Brexit and are more likely to climb down from their turrets in the final moments and try to make a deal now they are faced with a UK leader who seems unflinching, whatever the outcome. A favourable outcome would mean the pound would strengthen a little, but probably not a lot to start with until it becomes clear what the future holds. The markets are very skittish about uncertainty.

Based on current projection of possible no deal scenario. Investors will be looking to pick up selective stock market bargains which will be the only thing supporting the pound as the UK has foregone all the economic advantages that come from being inside a major trading block. Now with no leverage against much bigger players, it will take a generation to recover, if ever.
Considering the minimum so far has been 1.06 at the time of highest uncertainty there's no reason the value will go below that this year. Next year tough... dire times
There is no reason for it to drop below parity. No one really knows what is going to happen after Brexit. Uncertainty is what drives these mechanisms
Pound likely to fall with hard brexit on the other hand European Union loses one of its biggest training partners amid weakening global economy

With the high probability of either a hard Brexit or increasing political instability in the UK (even in the event of an opposition takeover), the GBP, lacking support for guaranteed trade deals outside of the EU, has the prospects of landing in a sea of lack of confidence.
Expect to see a slight drop in both the Pound and the Euro due to a no deal Brexit.
I think expectation of a no deal Brexit is already factored into the current exchange rate.

It’s on a downward trend and that’s so close to the major changes, people will flounder and the pound will lose value until things stabilize. Timing for the devaluation is a little tricky. Depends on how fast people feel the shock. People don’t like change.

the pound dropped below 1.2 euros after the brexit vote and hasn't been above since then. seems that it will continue to drop with the exit. not sure how fast the market will respond one day after the leave is scheduled.

the pound to euro drifted to 1.06 before rebounding to 1.09 
When Parliament reconvenes in a couple of weeks - reassess based on NCV and fallout.
It seemed to hard to believe that the pound would strengthen against the euro in this time period. 
To me that would require BOE to raise rates. But Brexit, hard or soft, will probably require BOE easing for a weaker currency for industry exporters to continue to be competitive. 
So I halved the chance of strengthening from 1.10 to 1.20 - even though the pound to euro is 1.09+ today
Which currency will collapse the fastest? Possibly both crash equally and it's Deuchmarks uber Alle..
EURGBP is typically between 1.0 and 1.2, with Brexit no deal more likely, the range is more likely towards the lower of the long term range.
Because there’s a chance that no-deal will be bad, but that no Brexit would see the £ really rise

Current trading seems to be sitting consistently between 1-1.1. That suggests to me that a no deal Brexit will break the 1 EUR mark. Negotiating an extension however could generate a rally, but I think the more likely outcome is more of the same

A no-deal Brexit seems to be thought increasingly likely by many pundits. If so the pound will fall, and is very unlikely to strengthen (but you never know). How far will it fall? I don’t know so have made all falling possibilities equal probability, for now. Should I get more information, of course I will adjust my forecasts. This question is phrased a little ambiguously, since I wasn’t sure which way round the rate was being quoted.
Probably nearer parity as pound weakens steadily

In the last month the exchange value has fluctuated from 1.12 and 1.06 with a clear downward trend, clearly spearheaded by the new UK PM stance on no-deal Brexit as a likely option.
In the previous two months, roughly before the new PM took charge, the value had fluctuated from 1.15 to 1.12. For the whole of the last 12 months the highest point was 1.18, reached around the time of the March exit extension . It's very uncertain what will happen after 31 October regarding Brexit, but so far the wisdom of crowds in this site vouch for a new extension of the deadline to leave the UK. Such an outcome will not remove uncertainty but might return the status quo to pre-Boris Johnson post-30 March 2019 times, thus my prediction for the sterling to more likely be more than 1.10 but less than 1.20
Because the outcome of Brexit is unclear but could go either way. If Brexit does not happen the markets will still be nervous and the £ will be unlikely to rise above 30%

The pound has only headed in one direction since the EU ref in June 2016 and is not too far off parity as of Aug 2019. Whilst short term economic trends across the Europe aren't great, the expectation is that the pound will remain weak given the barriers to trade that a no deal Brexit may bring. However given the current uncertainty around a no deal and the judicial process that has just started to stop a no deal, as well as the speaker of the HoC unwilling to accept the closure of Parliament, I think that the most likely option is actually for Johnson to have to backtrack on the 31st October deadline, which may bring about a bounce to the pound to above the €1.10 mark
The recent trajectory of the exchange rate suggest the Pound will continue to go down until no-deal remains a likely scenario. I expect this to remain the case until the very end of October.
My assumption is that there will be a no-deal Brexit; but even under other scenarios there will still be a huge amount of uncertainty which will likely cause the pound to fall against the Euro.
Working with the assumption that the UK will leave without a deal, which will provide additional downward pressure on an already weak pound.

A lot of factors at play here:
1. Large Current Account Deficit (must be offset by a Capital Account Surplus or the Currency will depreciate)
2. Political risks that can't be ignored
3. A Central Bank that believes a week currency will benefit the UK (offset any tariff impacts) All of these factors would support Sterling falling further than its' current price of 1.098, but I'm trying to untangle what might be priced in already. For this question, I started with the option-implied volatility on 3-mo contracts and used it to calculate the probability of each bucket based on the ranges. My results indicate:
<1: 22%
1 - 1.1: 33%
1.1 - 1.2: 30%
1.2 - 1.3: 13%
> .3: 3% From this base rate I chose to use the relative economic strength approach to tweak my forecasts. General consensus seems to be that the EU can weather a hard Brexit (96% likely according to betting markets) better than the UK. Brexit has already hit UK GDP, national income, and business investment. Meanwhile, I don't buy the argument that the EU will substantially lose by virtue of a smaller market for two reasons:
1. Businesses, consumers, and even the government are already stockpiling goods from the bloc
2. Supply/Demand dynamics say that (in the absence of another major trading partner) demand for EU products force UK consumers to bear the costs of tariffs and duties These factors make me increase my probability in the 1 -1.1 bin (thinking the Pound will fall to the lower part of the range), but reduce it in the <1 bin (I think these options are mostly OTM hedgers) and >1.2 bins. In order to believe higher, I'd need to see a major shift in the Johnson administration and Brussels positions. That being said the "priced-in hard brexit rate" seems to be 1.09 for now so some upside risk remains

When the talk of Brexit was highest in 2019   - the pound actually strengthened from 1.10775 EUR/1 GBP  to 1.17565, a 5.85% increase. Normally, when one sees a national trade impact on the horizon, a currency weakens. Taking as baseline June 23 2016 (date of Brexit referendum) (1.30541 EUR/1GBP)  it took out all prior lows since 2011, and created a new low of 1.10651 on Oct 14 2016.
It then tested and penetrated that low, and established a new low of 1.07965 Aug 30, 2017.
Since then it's established a rough +- 7% trading range from 1.10404 (Aug 27, 2018) to 1.17576 (May 6, 2019). Then it collapsed almost straight down - 5.6% to its present 1.11293 (and is slightly off a recent bottom). A strengthening would arise from stable government and higher central bank rates. Neither is present, and neither is likely through Nov 1 2019. 
In fact no central bank - BOE, the Fed, ECB - seem ready to do anything other than to return to low rates and QE if needed. We've seen enough European negative yield bonds to see that is the ECB's go-to move to keep European commerce going. The other two can't be far behind in their thinking. Given likely trade disruptions post-Brexit alone, UK would advantaged by using a weaker currency so as to sell abroad (but will hurt when they have to import a total of USD $673 billion and pay in a week currency. Looks like a future baking-in of inflation ("money chasing money"). Total imports account for about 1/4 of UK 2018 GDP of USD $2.7 trillion. So it looks like a weaker currency for the pound on Nov 1 2019 - but how much weaker? If indeed Brexit is already baked into the present 1.11293 EUR/ 1 GBP, I don't see another precipitous decline, given they will be voting for a PM who everybody knows will carry out a hard Brexit. 
I do see a trading range of 5% upside from here (1.1686 EUR/1 GBP) and 10% downside(1.0016 EUR/1 GBP) - with more confidence in a further erosion of the pound than in any strengthening.
And if it does indeed pop through the 1.10327 floor set on Dec 12 2018 - and my trading range reflects that it does penetrate the prior low - -no telling how far it will fall from there...... (I sure hope I got my EUR/GBP notations and pricings right!!)

At time of developing this forecast the rate was 1GBP to 1.11EUR.  Outlook for GBP bearish from here as markets continue to price in some hope for a business-friendly resolution of the crisis. In actual fact there is now no mechanism in place to avoid a hard Brexit, which is bearish for Sterling with a downside in excess of 10% due to trade disorder, decreased competitiveness of UK goods in Europe and increased import costs for UK consumers. Also uncertainty around Scotland and NI subsequently opting to leave the UK in order to maintain access to European markets in the event of a disorderly Brexit is an ongoing long term tailwind for Sterling that’s not fully priced in yet. This will price in fully once markets accept inevitability of a hard / no-deal Brexit. The reason why there is no mechanism to avoid hard Brexit is due to 100% certainty that the next PM, whoever it is, has already committed themselves to the path of a no-deal Brexit without the possibility of another outcome. The Brexit wing of the Tory party have effectively completed their take-over of the party with the clear intent to pursue Brexit at all costs. Markets have not yet adequately priced in the behavior change in the Tory party: specifically that traditional Tory behavior of pursuing market-friendly policies can no longer be relied on. Commitment to a non-customs union Brexit has become the superordinate goal of Tory leaders. This outcome can only be avoided if a general election takes place prior to October 2019. I view this probability is low due to Brexit group determination to cling to power until “job is done”. A vote of no-confidence could trigger a collapse of the new government and trigger an election, this also seems unlikely (less than 5%). Moreover, this unlikely chain of events would not lead to a substantial improvement in Sterling inside the Horizon of my forecast beyond my base case, at best we might expect Sterling to trade where it is today due to ongoing uncertainty. My forecast reflects this. My mental model for forming this view is strongly influenced by the work of AJP Taylor, notably his book “how wars begin”. This is not a war, obviously; however the book demonstrates how political actors can set in motion chains of events that they themselves subsequently lose control of (in the book, essentially, all courses of action except war are closed off making it inevitable).

The futures market's currently at ~1.106 (https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/fx/g10/euro-fx-british-pound.html), with movement of the July rate about 0.05 since April, so using that as standard deviation odds'd probably be around 2%, 43%, 52%, 3%, 0%. But the downside scope (~30% chance of no deal, which'd spark a drop larger than the referendum result's) is likely larger than the upside (article 50 revocation's very unlikely, and without it there'll remain a lot of uncertainty), so I'll equally weight that distribution, a 'no deal' ~0.1 drop, and a counterbalancing upwards-skewed distribution. But, tbh, ????

Two major competing variables each made up of many strong subset variables make finding the key factor(s) in determining the outcome of the question very difficult.  There are the economic influences on currency exchange rates which can be based on the  performance of either economy or the two in relationship to each other.  There is the political environment of either of the two or both.  The UK and the EU at this moment both have economies that are less than healthy and both have plenty of political problems and uncertainties that involve much more than the relationship between each other.  I am assuming at this point no major change from the current currency relationship by November as factors other than Brexit will determine the level of the currencies translation.  The bigger movement on the exchange rates may be between the Euro and Pound relative to the dollar and other major currencies.
